claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.

attacks.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.
The increase in working hours may be due to part-time workers shifting to full-time roles, not necessarily longer hours for the same individuals.
Even if part-time workers shifted to full-time roles, the overall average still reflects increased total working hours across the population.
The statistics do not account for unpaid overtime or informal work, which may have decreased, offsetting the official increase.
Studies on unpaid overtime show it has remained stable or increased, further supporting the claim of longer working hours.
The data may not reflect recent trends, such as post-pandemic remote work, which could reduce effective working hours despite official counts.

supporting.text: The rise of remote work and digital connectivity has blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer working hours.

attacks.text: The rise of remote work and digital connectivity has blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer working hours.
Studies show that remote work often increases flexibility, allowing workers to better manage their time and reduce total working hours.
While flexibility exists, many remote workers report difficulty disconnecting from work, leading to unpaid overtime and longer hours.
Official labor statistics indicate that average weekly working hours in England have remained stable or slightly decreased over the past decade.
Labor statistics may not fully capture informal or unpaid work time, especially in remote settings, underreporting actual hours worked.
The blurring of boundaries affects only knowledge workers, while manual and service workers still maintain strict work-hour separations.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have forced many people to work longer hours or take on additional jobs.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have forced many people to work longer hours or take on additional jobs.
Technological advancements and remote work have increased productivity, allowing people to work fewer hours while maintaining the same output.
Despite productivity gains, many industries still require long hours due to understaffing and high workloads, countering the reduction in hours.
Government policies and labor laws in England have reduced maximum working hours and increased protections for workers.
Enforcement of labor laws is inconsistent, and many workers, especially in gig economy jobs, still work excessive hours without proper compensation.

supporting.text: Historical data indicates that leisure time has decreased in England over the past few decades, suggesting more time is spent working.

attacks.text: Historical data indicates that leisure time has decreased in England over the past few decades, suggesting more time is spent working.
The decrease in leisure time could be due to factors other than work, such as increased time spent on household responsibilities or commuting.
Studies show that household responsibilities have not increased significantly, and commuting times have remained stable in England over the same period.
Technological advancements have made work more efficient, potentially reducing actual working hours despite the decrease in leisure time.
Surveys indicate that many workers in England report feeling busier and working longer hours despite technological advancements.

supporting.text: The gig economy and flexible work arrangements have led to more people working irregular or extended hours compared to traditional 9-to-5 jobs.

attacks.text: The gig economy and flexible work arrangements have led to more people working irregular or extended hours compared to traditional 9-to-5 jobs.
Many gig economy jobs are part-time or side hustles, meaning workers may actually work fewer total hours than full-time employees.
Studies show that gig workers often take on multiple jobs to compensate for low pay, leading to longer overall working hours.
Flexible work arrangements often allow people to work more efficiently, reducing the need for extended hours.
Remote work can blur boundaries between work and personal life, leading to unpaid overtime and longer working hours.

supporting.text: Surveys report that a higher percentage of employees in England now work overtime compared to previous decades.

attacks.text: Surveys report that a higher percentage of employees in England now work overtime compared to previous decades.
Overtime does not necessarily mean more total working hours, as standard working hours may have decreased.
Historical data shows that standard working hours have remained stable or slightly increased, reinforcing the link between overtime and total working time.
Surveys may not account for underreporting of overtime in previous decades due to less stringent labor regulations.
Modern survey methodologies and stricter reporting requirements make current data more reliable than historical comparisons.
